coredata.dc:description: Anode-free lithium–metal batteries (AFLMBs) are ideal candidates for achieving high-energy density electrochemical energy storage (EES) devices by eliminating the need for a conventional graphite electrode or excess lithium–metal anode. Those AFLMBs severely suffer from low Coulombic efficiency (CE), and long cyclability due to the loss of Li inventory in the cathode to uncontrollable side reactions. Advanced electrolyte development is a promising route to maximize lithium-inventory retention rate (LIRR) and minimize capacity fade. However, a poor understanding of the mechanisms by which advanced electrolytes improve performance hampers progress in the practical development of AFLMBs. In this study, the 1 M LiDFOB in EC/DMC (1:1, v/v %) + 1 wt% LiDFP +1 wt% FEC (denoted as DDEDF) has been chosen as an alternative liquid electrolyte for AFLMBs. The electrolyte properties of the DDEDF electrolyte in asymmetric and symmetric configurations were systematically studied and compared with the electrochemical performances of conventional LP30 electrolyte (1 M LiPF6 in EC/DMC (1:1, v/v %)) used for LMBs. The AFLMB based on DDEDF electrolyte delivered an enhanced cyclability (100 cycles) and superior LIRR retention (99.10 %) than the LP30 electrolyte. Based on those results, we found that our DDEDF shows highly promising as an alternative liquid electrolyte for the AFLMB practical application.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Anode-free lithium–metal batteries (AFLMBs) are ideal candidates for achieving high-energy density electrochemical energy storage (EES) devices by eliminating the need for a conventional graphite electrode or excess lithium–metal anode. Those AFLMBs severely suffer from low Coulombic efficiency (CE), and long cyclability due to the loss of Li inventory in the cathode to uncontrollable side reactions. Advanced electrolyte development is a promising route to maximize lithium-inventory retention rate (LIRR) and minimize capacity fade. However, a poor understanding of the mechanisms by which advanced electrolytes improve performance hampers progress in the practical development of AFLMBs. In this study, the 1 M LiDFOB in EC/DMC (1:1, v/v %) + 1 wt% LiDFP +1 wt% FEC (denoted as DDEDF) has been chosen as an alternative liquid electrolyte for AFLMBs. The electrolyte properties of the DDEDF electrolyte in asymmetric and symmetric configurations were systematically studied and compared with the electrochemical performances of conventional LP30 electrolyte (1 M LiPF6 in EC/DMC (1:1, v/v %)) used for LMBs. The AFLMB based on DDEDF electrolyte delivered an enhanced cyclability (100 cycles) and superior LIRR retention (99.10 %) than the LP30 electrolyte. Based on those results, we found that our DDEDF shows highly promising as an alternative liquid electrolyte for the AFLMB practical application.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: Data will be made available on request.

ce:section.ce:para: Lithium metal batteries (LMBs) are regarded as a highly promising replacement to traditional lithium-ion batteries, due to their remarkable theoretical specific capacity of 3860 mAh g−1 and exceptionally low redox potential of −3.04 V (vs. SHE) [1,2]. As the demand for higher-energy batteries grows, the cost of lithium metal is skyrocketing, this highlights the urgent need for innovative strategies to fully realize the potential of LMBs [3]. One way to lower the cost is by moving away from Li metal anodes and adopting anode-free batteries, which have no lithium metal anode in its discharged state (N/P = 0), offering a simpler and more efficient choice. Apart from the cost, lithium metal in excess possesses safety risks due to its high reactivity. Anode-free lithium metal batteries (AFLMBs) with in-situ formed lithium metal as the anode can deliver similar performance to LMBs, also capable of exceeding the performance of commercial lithium-ion batteries [4–6]. However, the AFLMBs have a significant limitation stemming from lithium inventory loss. This emerges as the critical challenge in achieving an efficient Li-ion shuttle from the cathode [7,8]. Due to the high reactivity of lithium, side reactions are unavoidable, resulting in the formation of excessive solid-electrolyte interphase (SEI) and dead lithium, both of which result in inventory depletion and poor cycling stability of AFLMBs [9,10]. To ensure the sustainability of energy storage technologies, advancing research on AFLMBs should be prioritized.

Apart from tuning the current collectors (CC) and protective layer coating onto the Li metal anodes, implementing Li-friendly ether-based electrolytes (high-concentration electrolytes, HCEs or localized-high concentration electrolytes, LHCEs) and in-situ tuning of SEI with liquid electrolyte additives have gained more attention [11]. They offer high Coulombic efficiency (CE%) and high reductive stability to the batteries [7,12,13]. However, ether-based electrolytes exhibit poor oxidative stability at high voltage, which severely degrades the battery performance; HCEs, and LHCEs are associated with excessive cost and poor ionic conductivity issues [14].

To overcome these challenges, it is better to go with carbonate-based electrolytes with functional additives, such as vinylene carbonate (VC), fluoro-ethylene carbonate (FEC), and so on [15,16]. The conventional Li-ion electrolyte, LP30 comprised of 1 M LiPF6 in EC/DMC (1:1, v/v %) was one of the best electrolytes so far (others being LP40, LP57, etc.), especially regarding the graphite anodes and the aluminum (Al) foil cathode current collector due to its passive film-forming ability and high-voltage stability of >5.5 V [16]. Many researchers have verified that the nature of electrolytes affects the cyclability of Li metal batteries (LMBs) [17–20]. Even though LiPF6 and carbonate-solvents form a stable SEI layer in a Li-ion battery; for a Li-metal anode is detrimental resulting from the high reactivity of Li-metal. As AFLMBs employ no Li anode, the effects were worse since the cathode is their only Li inventory, and those functional additives, especially FECs, have poor shelf-life in the presence of LiPF6 [21,22].

Zhang in 2006, first reported the use of lithium difluoro(oxalato)borate (LiDFOB) via modified lithium (bis-oxalato)borate (LiBOB), as a lithium salt for the electrolyte of lithium-ion batteries [23]. As an inorganic-organic hybrid salt of LiBOB and lithium tetrafluoro borate (LiBF4), LiDFOB resulted in a dual nature SEI layer with oligomeric ether outer layer and robust inorganic inner layer [24–26]. Usually, LiDFOB is well-known for forming better cathode-electrolyte interface (CEI), but also associated with easier decomposition and more gas evolution resulting in roll-over failure, so it cannot be used as a single salt in liquid electrolytes [27–29]. LiBF4, lithium (bis-trifluoro sulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI), and lithium nitrate (LiNO3) are previously reported as co-salts for LiDFOB to achieve a stable performance in high-voltage Li-metal batteries [29–32]. Lithium difluoro-phosphate (LiDFP) has been reported to enhance the rate capability of graphite||NMC cells and reduce the interfacial resistance when used as an electrolyte additive [33,34]. The CEI layer derived from LiDFP was further known to suppress the decomposition of electrolyte, transition-metal dissolution and avoid cracking associated with nickel-rich cathode materials like NCM811 or NCA [35].

Although, it has been reported that LiDFP eventually produced organo-fluoro phosphates (OFPs), a potentially toxic chemical that limits its wide usage. In 2022, Johannes et al., reported the stabilization of LiDFP by the addition of FEC as co-additive in equal proportion to the conventional LP57 (1 M LiPF6 in EC/EMC, 3:7, v/v%) liquid electrolyte in LMBs [36]. They have verified that both additives aided synergistically each other for better cycling performance. Earlier in 2020, Shigeto et al., verified that the addition of LiDFP could promote the shelf-life of FEC by suppressing its side-reaction with other Li-salts [34]. Moreover, FEC helps increase the contact-ion pair in liquid electrolytes, favoring a lithium fluoride (LiF)-rich compound in SEI layer [37].

Based on the above reports, herein we for the first time report the use of 1 M LiDFOB in EC/DMC (1:1, v/v %) + 1 wt% LiDFP +1 wt% FEC (denoted as DDEDF) as an alternative new liquid electrolyte for AFLMBs. The electrochemical properties of the DDEDF electrolyte showed that it has the potential to replace conventional LP30 electrolyte in the aspect of Li-metal batteries when used against two-dimensional (2-D) CC. We utilized a single-faceted Cu foil (hereafter denoted as m-Cu) from our previous work as a CC in our AFLMBs. As a result, this new DDEDF electrolyte in a m-Cu||NCM811 anode-free cell retained a capacity of 40.46 % (capacity retention; CR%) at the 100th cycle. It also showed a lithium-inventory retention rate (LIRR) of 99.10 % for 100 cycles. Our DDEDF liquid electrolyte could be a reliable, efficient, and friendly alternative for the Li-metal anodes, especially for the AFLMB application.

Carbon-coated aluminum foil, LiNi0.8Co0.1Mn0.1O2 powder, and liquid electrolyte 1 M LiPF6 in EC/DMC (1:1, v/v %) (referred to as LP30) were obtained from UBIQ Technology Co., Ltd., Taiwan. Polyethylene (PE) membrane (thickness, δ = 15 μm) was obtained from Asahi Kasei Corp., Japan. The borate-based liquid electrolyte 1 M LiDFOB in EC/DMC (1:1, v/v %) + 1 wt% LiDFP +1 wt% FEC (hereafter referred to as DDEDF) was also supplied by UBIQ Technology Co., Ltd., Taiwan on request.

The thermally modified single-faceted Cu (m-Cu) foil from our previous work was utilized for all the electrochemical studies [38]. It was obtained from the commercial battery grade rolled-annealed copper foil (RA-Cu; UBIQ Technology Co., Ltd., Taiwan) by a one-step surface reconstruction under high temperature. The experimental procedure, in brief, is as follows, the commercial Cu (c-Cu) foil was cleaned with 0.5 M H2SO4, water, and acetone in sequence and put into the tube furnace. The furnace temperature was ramped to 600 °C at the rate of 5 °C min−1 under 5 % H2/95%Ar (in reducing atmosphere) gas flow and held up for 2 h at this temperature. After cooling down the furnace, the as-obtained m-Cu foil was cold-pressed to flatten it and then punched into 15 mm (diameter) discs. Finally, the m-Cu discs were transferred to the glove box to avoid contamination and for cell assembly.

The positive electrodes are based on the composition of NCM811 cathode material: Super P: VGCF: PVDF with a weight percent of 90:4:1:5, respectively. The mixture was centrifugally mixed for 2 h in a Thinky mixer. And the resulting slurry was cast onto the carbon-coated aluminum foil followed by drying under 60 °C overnight under a vacuum. Then, the electrodes were calendered and punched into 13 mm (diameter) discs, and stored in the glove box for further cell assembly. The active material mass loading of the NCM cathodes was approximately 7.5 mg cm−2 (theoretical areal capacity = 1.5 mAh cm−2).

The plane orientations and grain size of the Cu foils were investigated using a Scanning-electron microscope equipped with Bruker ED-XS detector (Hitachi SU-8700 at the Bruker Nano-Analytics facility, Taiwan). The electronic conductivity of the Cu foils from its sheet resistance was interpreted using a manual four-point probe surface resistivity measurement instrument (Napson RT-70 V, Napson Corporation; Japan). To determine the elemental compositions and oxidation states in the SEI layer, and CEI layer, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (PHI5000VersaProbe III, ULVAC-PHI, Inc.; Japan) was applied. The morphology of the plated lithium metal on different Cu foils was observed using an Ultra High-Resolution Schottky Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope (FE-SEM, JEOL Ltd.; Japan). The cross-section of plated lithium metal on m-Cu foil under different electrolytes were studied using a High-Resolution Dual-Beam Focus Ion Beam SEM System (FIB-SEM, FEI Versa 3D; USA).

Symmetric and asymmetric cells with the configuration of Li||Li and Li||Cu (or stainless steel (SS) or carbon paper (CP) in certain cases), respectively, were used to study the different electrolytes in CR2032 coin-type cells. The electrochemical impedance spectrum (EIS), linear-sweep voltammetry (LSV), and cyclic voltammetry (CV) tests of each cell were determined using a multichannel electrochemical workstation (SP-300, Bio-Logic; France). The plating-stripping measurements, galvanostatic charge/discharge (GCD) experiment, and coulometric-titration time analysis (CTTA) were conducted through a computer-controlled system (CT-4008 T-5 V 50 mA, Neware Technology Limited; China). The anode-free full cells were based on NCM811||PE||Cu configuration. All the cells were assembled in CR2032 coin-type cells in an argon-filled glovebox (O2 and H2O ≤ 0.5 ppm), and were aged for 24 h before the GCD experiment between 3.0 and 4.2 V at 0.2 (charge)/0.5 (discharge) mA cm−2 at room temperature (RT). All the coin cells employed 60 μL of the liquid electrolytes either 1 M LiDFOB in EC/DMC (1:1, v/v %) + 1 wt% LiDFP +1 wt% FEC or 1 M LiPF6 in EC/DMC (1:1, v/v %).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Modification of commercial copper foil current collector
ce:section.ce:para: With the help of Electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD) analysis, the results of the commercial Cu (c-Cu) foil and modified Cu (m-Cu) foil current collectors (CCs) are shown in Figs. S1(a-f). The difference in the grain size of c-Cu and m-Cu foils was seen in their respective pattern quality maps (high-resolution SEM images). The average grain size of c-Cu foil was around 1.0 μm, while that of the as-modified m-Cu foil was approximately 16.3 μm. With the increase in grain size, the grain boundaries in the crystal will get reduced. The decrease in the grain boundaries resulted in the enhanced electronic conductivity of the m-Cu foil (obtained using Nason-70 V; see Table S1). Both the EBSD spectrum and XRD pattern in Fig. S1(g) confirmed that the m-Cu foil was single-faceted with more pronounced lithiophilic Cu (200) planes (family of (100) planes) [38,43]. With enhanced electronic conductivity and lithiophilicity, the as-modified copper (m-Cu) has been chosen as a promising CC for the characterization and coin cell electrochemical performance studies.

A commercial liquid electrolyte should have good ionic conductivity, be capable of charge transferring effectively at the electrode-electrolyte interface and have fast Li+ ion diffusion. Fig. 1(a) shows the ionic-conductivity measurement (
σ
Li +
) of the electrolytes of LP30 and DDEDF, employed in Li||PE||SS asymmetric cell configuration calculated from their respective bulk resistance (Rb), using Eq.(1 & 2). LP30 electrolyte shows better ionic conductivity of 7.8 × 10−4 S cm−1 (7.8 × 10−1 cm2 S equiv.−1), benefitting due to the larger size of PF6ֿ ions, while DDEDF electrolyte shows ca. 6.5 × 10−4 S cm−1 because of its better degree of salt dissociation in carbonate solvents . The equivalent ionic conductivity (
Λ
Li +
) of DDEDF electrolyte was 5.8 × 10−1 cm2 S equiv.−1 with respect to the concentration Li+ ions and 6.6 × 10−1 cm2 S equiv.−1 with respect to the concentration DFOB− ions (B-compound) [44,45]. In Fig. 1(b), the linear sweep voltammetry profile depicting the electrochemical stability window for the electrolytes was given, its enlarged profile was presented in Figs. S2(a)&(b). The Li+ cation intercalation in carbon paper shows the onset potential at 0.65 V, while the anion intercalation (hexafluoro phosphate anion, PF6ֿ or difluoro(oxalato) borate anion, DFOB−) happens around 5.17 V in both electrolytes [46]. It is well-known that LP30 has better electrochemical stability than all the other commonly electrolyte used Li-ion battery. Our DDEDF electrolyte showed a similar stability window against the Li reference when assessed with a carbon paper working electrode. This exceptional stability inspired us to employ this electrolyte for high-voltage Ni-rich cathode-based batteries. However, the LiDFOB salt was reported to exhibit severe roll-over fading, additional functional additives, such as LiBF4, LiNO3, or LiDFP can be used to avoid the fast fading [27–29]. For the DDEDF electrolyte, the reductive decomposition of FEC happens around 1.5 V, which is earlier due to the presence of electronegative F−. Meanwhile, the LP30 reveals the decomposition of EC at around 1.1 V [37,47]. On the anodic oxidation direction, at around 4.5 V both electrolytes showed [solvent-anion] complex decomposition peak. The carbonate solvents are prone to decomposition on the surface of carbon electrodes (this behavior is spontaneous in the case of the Li electrode) forming passivation layers [48,49]. The current response of DDEDF electrolyte was relatively low on the cathodic side due to the presence of LiDFP additive, which was added to promote high voltage stability [35].

Nucleation overpotential measurements were presented in Figs. 1(c & d), for both the electrolytes at 0.2 and 0.5 mA cm−2, respectively, in a Li||PE||m-Cu asymmetric cell. The lower nucleation overpotential of DDEDF (ca. 33.9 and 51.4 mV) suggests that it has low charge-transfer resistance for Li plating onto the Cu foil [50,51]. The LP30 electrolyte even though it had good ionic conductivity, and better electrochemical stability showed an exceedingly high nucleation overpotential of 199.2 and 252.2 mV at 0.2 and 0.5 mA cm−2, respectively. We extended the ionic conductivity and nucleation overpotential measurements to three other electrolytes viz., DED (1 M LiDFOB in (1:1 v/v%) EC/DMC), DEDF (1 M LiDFOB in (1:1 v/v%) EC/DMC + 1 % FEC), and DDED (1 M LiDFOB in (1:1 v/v%) EC/DMC + 1 % LiDFP) to emphasize the benefit of additives. The nucleation overpotential data was shown in Fig. S2(c), while Fig. S2(d) shows the ionic conductivity experiment results. All three electrolytes showed a higher nucleation overpotential than DDEDF electrolyte but were better than LP30. Table S2 compares the nucleation overpotential of our electrolyte system with electrolytes used in other reported literatures. Based on the comparison it is rational to believe that the composition of electrolyte system will affect the nucleation of Li plating on to the current collector. Encouragingly, our DDEDF electrolyte significantly reduced the nucleation overpotential without any use of alloying interfacial layer. Furthermore, ionic conductivity results mentioned in Table S3 have the following trend: LP30 > DDED > DDEDF > DEDF > DED.

To delve deeper into the electrolytes' charge-transfer kinetic properties, Tafel plot experiments were conducted using Li||PE||Li symmetric cells, as shown in Figs. 2 (a & b), at 5 mV s−1 scan rate. A faster charge transfer rate at the electrode-electrolyte interface will be marked by a higher exchange current density, j
0 , measured using Eq. (3) [38]. The initial j
0 of DDEDF electrolyte was around 0.139 mA cm−2, while that of LP30 was three times lesser (ca. 0.0413 mA cm−2), suggesting a poor charge-transfer kinetic behavior at the interface. Simultaneously, in the non-Tafel region of the Tafel plots the charge-transfer resistance, R
ct was evaluated using Eqns. (4) and (5) [38,52]. The initial R
ct values of LP30 and DDEDF electrolytes were approximately 365.16 and 116.10 Ω, respectively, as shown in Fig. 2(c). The same trend was also reflected in the EIS measurements of the symmetric cells initially and after 10 cycles. Both the j
0 and R
ct measurements confirmed that the charge-transfer properties of LP30 were worse, which resulted in high nucleation potential. In Figs. S3(a-c), Tafel and non-Tafel plots for symmetric cells after 10 plating-stripping cycles have been given. Even after cycling, the electrolytes maintained a similar trend in their j
0 values, but with considerable enhancement. With a j
0 of 0.182 mA cm−2, the DDEDF electrolyte ensured a stable SEI layer, favoring faster charge-transfer kinetics. In Fig. 2(d) symmetry cell's voltage-time profile at 0.5 mA cm−2 under 1 mAh cm−2 areal capacity was displayed for both electrolytes. Not surprisingly, we were found that LP30 electrolyte showed an unstable cycling performance and short-circuited completely around 200 h, while the DDEDF electrolyte showed a much more stable performance for >600 h. From the Nyquist plots of the symmetrical cells in Fig. 2(e) and Fig. S3(d), it was further confirmed that the LP30 has a three- to four-fold higher R
ct value of 356.20 Ω (303.78 Ω after 10 cycles) than the DDEDF electrolyte (104.74 Ω initially; then 69.29 Ω after 10 cycles). Thus, the EIS measurement results are consistent with Tafel plot measurement results.

Further, the Tafel-plot measurements were taken for the electrolytes DED (without any additive), DEDF (with 1 % FEC), and DDED (with 1 % LiDFP). The results shown in Figs. S4(a)-(c) suggest that all the LiDFOB containing electrolytes showed better exchange current densities than the conventional LP30 electrolyte, but poorer than our DDEDF electrolyte. Corresponding, Nyquist plots were reproduced in Fig. S4(d) for comparison. Since these results were in accordance with nucleation overpotential and ionic-conductivity measurements, we further narrow down our comparison to LP30 and DDEDF electrolytes.

To validate the higher nucleation overpotential and poor charge-transfer kinetics of LP30 electrolyte, we analyzed the Li plating morphology on m-Cu foil by using FE-SEM. The m-Cu foils were harvested from the asymmetric cells after plating 0.6 mAh cm−2 of Li electrochemically at 0.2 mA cm−2, as shown in Fig. 3 , along with their Li thickness measurement for both the electrolytes. The photograph images in Figs. 3(a & b) show that the Li plating in LP30 electrolyte has a rough, non-uniform texture with some spikes, while DDEDF shows a smooth, uniform texture. The theoretically calculated thickness of Li was around 2.91 μm and that of the CCs after 0.6 mAh cm−2 Li plating were approximately 41 μm for LP30 with volume expansion of 690.1 % and it was approximately 28 μm for DDEDF with 243.5 % volume expansion (as seen insets in Figs. 3(a) & (b) and refer Table S4 for thickness calculation; thickness of our m-Cu foil is ca. 18 μm). From the micrographs of Li plating in LP30 (as seen in Figs. 3(c)) the morphology of Li was found to be fiber-like with a diameter of few hundred nanometers. In the aspect of material science perspective, a larger surface area was associated with the Li particle of smaller size/dimension, leading to severe side reactions and enhanced polarization. This behavior of smaller particle size was mainly due to the high nucleation overpotential in LP30 electrolyte. Liu et al., they showed that the higher the nucleation overpotential, the smaller is the size of Li nuclei/seed [50]. Also, when there is poor lithiophilicity or poor charge-transfer property at the interface, the Li prefers to plate on the Li seeds rather than the current collector's surface, resulting in needle-like Li dendritic morphology. In Figs. 3(e), FE-SEM images of Li deposits in DDEDF electrolyte were shown for comparison, which had a mossy/chunk-like morphology composed of nano distorted-dodecahedral Li nuclei. The distortion was due to the SEI formation associated with carbonate solvents and highly reactive Li metals. Recently, Li et al., reported that the morphology of electroplated lithium deposits to be a rhombic dodecahedron (bcc crystal family) using a cryo-TEM experiment. They used a very high areal current of 1 A cm−2 to outpace the SEI formation on Li metal [53]. Thus, our borate-based DDEDF electrolyte was enough unreactive to achieve a somewhat closer morphology of the real Li deposits. From the FIB-SEM analysis we have found considerable differences in the cross-section of plated Li deposits on m-Cu. The LP30 electrolyte showed more voids and cracks (ref. Fig. 3(d)) compared to the DDEDF electrolyte (ref. Fig. 3(f)).

In Scheme 1 , the formation of oligomeric BF, and BO rich SEI components from the LiDFOB salt along with uniform mossy Li deposition was picturized. Conventional carbonate-based electrolytes were both good at graphite anodes and aluminum foil current collector-based cathodes by forming a stable passivation layer along with the LiPF6 salt. When it comes to the Li metal anodes these electrolytes show more reactive behavior as their reductive stability against Li metal was less, undergoing spontaneous decomposition and are unstable in the presence of any impurities. Also, the volume expansion of Li couldn't withstand these fragile carbonate-derived SEI, resulting in more side reactions and hence poor Coulombic efficiency (CE). The DDEDF with organic anion (DFOB−) was more stable with Li metal anode and helped in forming a hybrid (inorganic-organic) oligomeric SEI layer [25]. For a better understanding of both electrolytes, we adopted to use a modified Aurbach's CE test in a Li||PE||m-Cu asymmetric cell and the average CE for 25 cycles was calculated using Eq. (6) [42]. The current density for the plating-stripping was at 0.5 mA cm−2 with 1 mAh cm−2 plating areal capacity. A conditioning cycle of 4 mAh cm−2 plating capacity was added to ensure complete SEI formation and then m-Cu pre-deposited with 4 mAh cm−2 Li before further cycling. For the LP30 electrolyte it started to show severe concentration polarization for stripping, starting from the 73rd h (as shown in Fig. 4(a)). It showed an average CE of 80.69 % while the DDEDF electrolyte showed a much more stable performance with a CE of 98.68 % (as seen in Fig. 4(c)) and without concentration polarization. The cyclic voltammetry results of LP30 and DDEDF electrolytes are shown in Figs. 4(b) & (d) in the asymmetric cells. The current response of the LP30 cells was very low when compared with the DDEDF electrolyte, which again proves the high charge-transfer resistance for LP30 electrolyte. High charge-transfer resistance was related to the high overpotential and lower exchange current density (Eq. (5)), following Ohm's law [52]. The polarization profile, as shown in Fig. S5(a), discusses the selected overpotential trend of two electrolytes for 25 cycles. Conventional LP30 electrolyte shows huge polarization, starting from the first cycle and linearly increasing in the range of 40.2 and 62.5 mV. This drastic increment in the polarization may be a reason for the repeated formation of unstable SEI, while the DDEDF electrolyte with less polarization suggests much stable/uniform SEI layer. Our DDEDF electrolyte showed relatively low polarization and rose gradually in the range of 24.1 and 26.9 mV for 25 cycles.

Recently, Janek and Aktekin et al., introduced a new technique based on the conventional Karl-Fischer titrator, which they termed Coulometric-titration time-analysis (abbreviated as CTTA) as a tool for battery characterization. This technique quantifies the side reactions between Li metal anodes and solid electrolytes interface during the SEI formation [55]. The extension of this experiment in liquid electrolytes to examine the reactivity of different CCs was reported in our previous study [38]. In brief, a fixed amount of charge (Li-plating capacity) was applied stepwise and then allowed to reach a cut-off potential for each step (titration). From the FE-SEM images, it was clear that the two electrolytes resulted in different morphology for the Li-plating. Usually, the kinetics of side reactions were controlled by the morphology of the as-plated Li deposits, which in turn regulated by the nature of electrolytes. Figs. 4(e & f) show the CTTA trend results of the LP30 and DDEDF electrolytes, respectively. Commercial LP30 electrolyte consumed 75.31 μAh cm−2 of Li deposit in 400 h, while our DDEDF electrolyte consumed only 46.94 μAh cm−2 at the same time. The self-discharge current (rate) for LP30 was calculated to be 0.19 μA cm−2 and for DDEDF it was ca. 0.12 μA cm−2 (ref. Figs. S5(b) & (c)). This further confirms that our designed DDEDF electrolyte favors compact Li deposition and hence markedly reduced side reactions. Similarly, for the electrolytes DED, DEDF, and DDED the Aurbach's Coulombic Efficiency test was given in Fig. S6(a) as a comparison. All the three electrolytes showed a poorer performance than the DDEDF electrolyte (with dual additive). The corresponding polarization profile was shown in Fig. S6(b) for 25 cycles.

Full cells (LMB with thin Li layer ∼23 μm) were assembled with thin Li-foil integrated with Cu foil as anode to study the Li plating/stripping kinetics of two electrolytes. The N/P ratio of the full cell was ∼3.2 (ca. areal capacity of thin Li foil was ∼4.75 mAh cm−2), while the practical capacity of NCM811 was around 1.35 mAh cm−2. In Fig. 5(a), the Nyquist plots of full cells with LP30 and DDEDF electrolyte were shown. The Rct value of both electrolytes was in similar fashion to that of the symmetric cells discussed prior in section 3.2 and Fig. 2(e). Initially, the Rct value of LP30 was around 460 Ω while that of DDEDF was only 147 Ω. The Li+-ion diffusion coefficient (DLi +) was found from the Warburg plots, as shown in Fig. S7(a), the DDEDF electrolyte has a lower Warburg slope, which corresponds to relatively faster mass transport (diffusion) behavior (DLi + = 3.66 × 10−14 cm2 s−1) than the LP30 electrolyte (DLi + = 1.40 × 10−14 cm2 s−1) for the NCM811 cathode with a mass loading of around 7.5 mg cm−2. The lower in the Warburg slope was attributed to the large size DFOB− anion and its film-forming ability on the positive electrode along with the FEC additive [23,27,37]. Next in Fig. 5(b), the comparison of long-term cycling performances of DDEDF and LP30 electrolytes in full cells was displayed. The current density was chosen as 0.5 mA cm−2 to further relate with and mimic the anode-free full cells. At the N/P ratio of 3.2, the AFLMB with DDEDF electrolyte showed a capacity retention (CR%) of 90.90 % after 100 cycles with an average CE% of 99.71 % (excluding first cycle). While the full cell with LP30 electrolyte has only retained 71.18 % of its initial capacity for the 100th cycle (CE% = 99.64 %, excluding first cycle). There was increment in the initial cycle Coulombic efficiency (ICE) when the LP30 electrolyte (ICE = 91.63 %) was replaced with DDEDF electrolyte (ICE = 93.49 %). The GCD profiles of the full cells (LMBs) for two electrolytes are given in Figs. S7(b) & (c). In Table S5 our anode-free LMB test results were compared to those of earlier reported literature.

Finally, both the electrolytes were analyzed in anode-free LMB full cells (N/P = 0), based on NCM811 cathode with m-Cu foil as the anode CC. Fig. 5(c) shows the cyclic performance with CR% and the CE% for the AFLMBs. DDEDF electrolyte had a CE% of 98.65 % and retained 40.4 % of its initial discharge capacity after 100 cycles. While the LP30 electrolyte showed only CE% of 97.44 % with a low CR% of 10.40 % for 100 cycles. Conventionally, CE% can be related to the fading rate in a half-cell (LMB with excess Li), but the case of AFLMBs is different. As the cathode is the only Li inventory available here, Manthiram et al., introduced a new term called lithium inventory retention-rate (LIRR) to define the fading rate. Our cell with DDEDF electrolyte had a LIRR of 99.10 % as calculated based on eq. (7) while the cell with LP30 electrolyte showed a poor LIRR of 97.76 % for 100 cycles [7,56]. For anode-free LMB batteries, due to the Li inventory loss from the cathode, the OCV always tends to increase. This behavior can be clearly seen in the GCD profiles of DDEDF and LP30 electrolytes, as shown in Fig. 5(d) and Fig. S7(d), respectively. Rapid increment in the OCV trend of AFLMB utilizing LP30 shows that the side-reaction was uncontrollable, resulting in either dead lithium or thick SEI layer. Additionally, the initial cycle voltage-capacity curves for both electrolytes were given in Figs. S7(e) & (f) for comparison. The ICE of the passive DDEDF electrolyte was ca. 89.97 % and that of the very reactive LP30 electrolyte was ca. 85.30 %. This further confirms the better reversibility in DDEDF electrolyte also favorable for plating Li deposits on m-Cu CC [57]. Also, during the initial charging (plating of Li on m-Cu, and deintercalation of Li from NCM811) step the polarization was comparatively high in LP30 electrolyte (can be seen from the respective charge curve's angle). In Fig. S6 (c), the cycling performance AFLMBs in DED, DEDF, and DDED were shown for comparison.

The composition of SEI layers on the surface of CC anodes was analyzed using XPS characterization. After 2 formation cycles at a low current of 0.1 mA cm−2, the anode-free cells were disassembled in an Ar-filled glove box, carefully retrieved all the m-Cu foils, and all the samples were transferred using a vacuum-transfer (VT) box. Fig. 6 shows the fitted XPS profiles for the elements C 1 s (a), F 1 s (b), B 1 s (c), P 2p (d), (e) Li 1 s, and (f) O 1 s. The formation of oligomeric SEI in DDEDF electrolyte was confirmed from the more pronounced polymeric ether (-C-O-) peak positioned around 286 eV in Fig. 6(a) while the LP30 has a predominant carbon chain (-C-C-) peak around 284.6 eV [25]. Both LP30 and DDEDF electrolytes have a carbonyl ester (O=C-O-) peak at 289.5 eV [27]. The reason for the high polymeric ether in DDEDF was the decomposition of LiDFOB salt, while the ester and carbon chains were associated with the solvents' decomposition [38]. In the F 1 s spectra (Fig. 6(b)) both electrolytes show the LiF-rich based SEI layer from the peak at 684.3 eV. The SEI layer based on conventional LiPF6 salt with more -PF- bonds (686.5 eV) resulted in the enhanced polarization of the cells. However, the SEI layer derived from the LiDFOB salt is reinforced with -B-F- linkage (685.9 eV) [58]. The decomposition of LiDFOB was further confirmed in the B 1 s spectra (Fig. 6(c)), showing peaks at 192.5 eV (LiDFOB) and 191.5 eV (LixBOyFz) [59]. The LiDFP (Fig. 6(d)) additive present in the DDEDF electrolyte remained without severe decomposition (∼134.1 eV; LixPOFy/LiPO2F2) on the surface of the m-Cu foil [34,35]. While the salt LiPF6 underwent a series of decomposition upon cycling and resulted in the formation of LiPO2F2 (∼133 eV), LixPOFy (∼134.5 eV) and LixPFy (∼136.8 eV) species [46,60]. Furthermore, Li 1 s, and O 1 s spectra were highlighted in Figs. 6(c)& (d), respectively. For comparison the fitted XPS profiles for the CEI layer was given in the Fig. S8 and Fig. S9, for the electrolytes LP30 and DDEDF, respectively. The XPS elemental distribution of the SEI layer was shown in Fig. S10(a), which further suggests the formation of a more dead‑lithium or thicker SEI layer with excess Li-ions (active species) in the LP30 electrolyte, as predicted from the CTTA test of asymmetrical cells, and GCD profiles of AFLMBs. While the DDEDF shows possibilities for the B- and F-rich SEI layer with less percentage of Li-ions. Additionally, Fig. S10(b) shows the XPS elemental profile of the CEI layer for both the electrolytes. The LP30 electrolyte favored LiF, and carbon rich interface, while the DDEDF electrolyte favored boron, and oxygen rich interface. Both the composition of SEI and CEI reveals that the interfaces were reinforced with boron from the LiDFOB salt used as electrolyte. The LP30 electrolyte with LiPF6 salt is supposed to result in phosphorous derived interfaces but on the surface of the copper/lithium foil and NCM811 cathode this salt has no potential of forming a passivation layer. Without a stable passivation layer, LiPF6 can potentially corrode the Li-metal as shown by the CTTA experiment in the OCV condition.

Conclusively, the 1 M LiDFOB in EC/DMC (1:1, v/v %) + 1 wt% LiDFP +1 wt% FEC (denoted as DDEDF) has been chosen as an alternative liquid electrolyte for AFLMBs. The electrochemical properties of the DDEDF electrolyte in asymmetric configuration with Li metal exhibited superior performance, as compared to the conventional LP30 electrolyte in the aspect of high Aurbach's Coulombic efficiency (98.68 %). Under symmetric configuration, the electrochemical performance delivered better long cyclability (>600 h) and high exchange current density in the Tafel test. To verify the function of DDEDF in the full cell configuration based on m-Cu||NCM811 anode-free cell displayed a CR% of 40.46 % (capacity retention) at the 100th cycle with a lithium-inventory retention rate (LIRR) of 99.10 %. Based on our analysis results, the DDEDF liquid electrolyte can be an alternative for the Li-metal battery (LMB) and AFLMB's practical applications.
